text.text_translated:
Springsteen is different from many other popular singers.
He is almost 70 years old, but he still makes new music that is very popular.
He plays for many people in very big places.
He is still one of the very best.
This does not surprise me.
His songs tell our most important stories about us.
Think about his song "Born in the USA".
Those stories are as important today as they were in the past.

feedback.feedback:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6031 is critically below the required 0.75 threshold. The text fails to preserve the core message of the original.

- The primary failure is the loss of the causal link. The original text explains that Springsteen's success is a direct result of his storytelling. Your version presents his success and his storytelling as two separate, unrelated facts. This is a significant deviation from the original meaning.
- The phrase "remains at the top of his game" describes a continuous, active state of excellence. Your simplification, "He is still one of the very best," is a static description and loses the original's sense of dynamic performance.
- While the vocabulary and sentence structure are compliant with the A2 level, the simplification has resulted in a critical loss of meaning, as confirmed by the metric score.

Suggestion: Restore the cause-and-effect relationship. Combine sentences to show why he is successful. Example: 'He is still very popular because his songs tell our most important stories.' This re-establishes the logical connection from the original text.

best_attempt.text_translated:
Springsteen is different from many other popular singers.
He is almost 70 years old, but he still makes new music that sells very well.
He plays for many people in big stadiums.
He is still one of the very best performers.
This does not surprise me.
His songs tell our most important stories about who we are.
These stories are still very important today, like in his song "Born in the USA".
